Watching John Cassavetes film, Opening Night, I was reminded of something that Quentin Tarantino said once in an interview about personal experience in being a creator. He said:
“I don’t think there’s any kind of fear of what we bring. You get to know the person early on. It’s about what you bring to the project. Tune into what is accessible and honest and significant in your life. Learn when to play to your strengths, and when not to.”

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Centered on Miyazawa’s own life, the film depicts his adolescence in the countryside, the ideals he intensively wrote about, and his ideals in regards to human nature, the environment and society.

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William WiPosage and Yakima Cannody, it features government agent Lane Darling as "Ka-Ming"; emigrant keeper of the secret where the brilliant sunstone and gold dish were hidden by Zorro. MaLee Darling was also the stuntman. The action scene index alone is worth the price.
